content:
I heartily invite anyone interested to have a look at this PR, and the related #2850. It can maybe serve as a prototype for other back-and-forth arguments.
@Jalex Stark
@Aaron Anderson and I read through together. It looks great! We're looking at using the same framework to prove that the theory of the Rado graph is omega-categorical
I think the way you use cmp will make it natural to generalize most of the machinery to partial isomorphisms of relational structures.

That's good to hear! :-) The Rado graph sounds like a good next step. The key to any relational structure should be to prove an analogue of what I called separation: with the Rado graph this is axiomatic afaiu.
I think all I need to finish is a bunch of exercises with finsets

just to record a mistake I fell into when trying to apply these proofs to the Rado graph:
the proofs are simplified by the fact that equality can be recovered from your cmp function. for instance this is needed in order for partial_isos to be thought of as bijective functions between subsets. I added in this bijectivity as a new property of partial_iso and had to deal with nontrivial new proof obligations. Adding equality as one of the cmp outcomes is easier
